title.narrative: IR 1.6 ACCES A L ENVIRONNEMENT ASSAINI

description.narrative: IR 1.6: Communities get sustainable access to drinking water and use hygienic sanitation systems, and they adopt improved hygiene practices and undertake to protect and maintain a cleaner environment., which contributes to Hygiene, Sanitation, Wash In Schools And Ecd Centres, Water, Water Supply. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: CHILD SURVIVALPCR1: By end 2018, the proportion of children, newborns, families who benefit from high health impact quality interventions, including HIV Prevention of Mother to Child Transmission (PMTCT), nutrition, and water - sanitation - hygiene (WASH ) increases significantly and fairly, particularly in health sub-divisions and communities.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: IR 1.6: Communities get sustainable access to drinking water and use hygienic sanitation systems, and they adopt improved hygiene practices and undertake to protect and maintain a cleaner environment.

description.narrative: Since 2013, a total of 4,882,275 people and 679,119 school-aged children have benefited from improved WASH services in 5,238 villages and 1,727 schools. As a result, overall diarrheal morbidity in children under-five years reduced by 67% in targeted communities as of 2019. In 2019, 275,247 people in 300 newly-certified villages and 18,264 school children in 53 newly-certified schools gained sustainable access to safe drinking water, adequate sanitation, and hygiene. | Status:Met | As-of Date:08/02/2020
